claim: Per capita income is higher in the US than in Japan on average.

supporting.text: According to World Bank data, the US has consistently reported higher GDP per capita than Japan in recent years.

attacks.text: According to World Bank data, the US has consistently reported higher GDP per capita than Japan in recent years.
GDP per capita does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in the US than in Japan.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), the US still maintains a higher per capita income than Japan according to IMF data.
The World Bank data may not fully capture informal economic activities, which are more prevalent in Japan and could underreport actual income.
Informal economic activities are typically lower-income and would not significantly impact the per capita income comparison between the US and Japan.

supporting.text: The US economy has a higher average wage level compared to Japan, as indicated by OECD labor statistics.

attacks.text: The US economy has a higher average wage level compared to Japan, as indicated by OECD labor statistics.
OECD statistics do not account for purchasing power parity (PPP), which may adjust the real income difference between the US and Japan.
OECD data includes PPP-adjusted metrics, and even after adjustment, US wages remain higher than Japan's on average.
The wage gap may be offset by Japan's lower cost of living, making per capita income comparisons misleading without cost adjustments.
Even accounting for cost of living, US disposable income remains higher, as shown in OECD household income reports.
Wage statistics may not reflect income inequality, where a few high earners in the US skew the average upward.
Median income data from OECD also shows US figures surpassing Japan's, reducing the skewness concern.

supporting.text: Japan's aging population and lower labor force participation contribute to lower per capita income relative to the US.

attacks.text: Japan's aging population and lower labor force participation contribute to lower per capita income relative to the US.
Japan has higher productivity per worker than the US, which compensates for its lower labor force participation.
Higher productivity in Japan does not fully offset the income gap because of its shrinking workforce and economic stagnation.
The US has higher income inequality, which skews per capita income upward without reflecting median living standards.
Even accounting for inequality, US median income remains higher than Japan's due to overall economic dynamism.

supporting.text: The US has a larger and more dynamic service and technology sector, which drives higher income levels on average.

attacks.text: The US has a larger and more dynamic service and technology sector, which drives higher income levels on average.
Japan has a highly efficient manufacturing sector that contributes significantly to income levels, potentially offsetting the US advantage in services.
The US service and technology sectors are more globally dominant, attracting higher investment and wages compared to Japan's manufacturing sector.
Income inequality in the US is higher, meaning the average may be skewed by top earners, while Japan has a more equitable distribution.
Even with higher inequality, median incomes in the US still surpass those in Japan, supporting the claim.
Cost of living in Japan is lower, meaning real income comparisons might not favor the US as strongly.
Even adjusted for cost of living, US disposable incomes remain higher on average.

supporting.text: Exchange rate differences between the US dollar and the Japanese yen further reinforce the higher per capita income in the US.

attacks.text: Exchange rate differences between the US dollar and the Japanese yen further reinforce the higher per capita income in the US.
Exchange rates fluctuate frequently, and using them as a basis for comparison may not reflect the actual purchasing power parity (PPP) between the two countries.
PPP-adjusted income metrics are widely accepted for cross-country comparisons and show that the US still maintains a higher per capita income than Japan.
The cost of living in Japan is significantly lower than in the US, which means nominal income differences may not translate to higher real income.
Even accounting for cost of living, US per capita income remains higher when adjusted for purchasing power, as supported by OECD data.
